name: BBCWorld
text:
Investigating an outbreak isn‚Äôt unlike the work of a crime detective

So, six months on, what have scientists discovered whilst trying to contain coronavirus?

[Thread] 

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/eiS4jxovpy

name: BBCWorld
text:
Scene of the crime:

The first large outbreak took place at the Huanan Seafood Market in China in December 2019

But it‚Äôs unlikely this is where the virus first emerged 

The earliest human case now appears to have been almost 4 weeks earlier on 1 December
https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/mp0GdCmDtp

name: BBCWorld
text:
Profiling a killer: 

The first question is always, what is it? 

Scientists in Wuhan started looking at the virus‚Äôs genetic code

On 10 January, they discovered it was a novel coronavirus, 80% identical to Sars, a similar virus which emerged in 2003

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/7aUbxZ7Rm7

name: BBCWorld
text:
"This ultimately started in a bat. But we still don‚Äôt know how the virus got into humans‚Äù says Prof Kristian Andersen

It may have jumped from a bat, to another animal such as a pangolin, where it picked up some extra proteins - before reaching humans

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/NLKb6DyKn8

name: BBCWorld
text:
Why is coronavirus so deadly?:

The virus can only enter the human body one way - by attaching on to specific receptors in the human body known as ACE-2

The problem with ACE-2 is that they are everywhere, from your nose, lungs, heart, kidneys and brain

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/qojz9hztb0

name: BBCWorld
text:
Children account for less than 2% of cases 

Scientists think this is because they have fewer ACE-2 receptors in their lower lungs, compared to adults

But evidence as to whether children are any more / less likely to pass the virus on remains unclear

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/uQ3eMxoJKl

name: BBCWorld
text:
Race for a vaccine:

The virus multiplies and moves on with devastating efficiency

Despite six months of investigation and scientific discovery, scientists believe the only way to truly bring an end to the pandemic is with a vaccine

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/E9Fc5Axxxu

name: BBCWorld
text:
124 different groups are currently vying to be the first to develop a vaccine against Covid-19

‚ÄúThe winner will be the vaccine that works for the most amount of people - ideally 90%" says Professor Kalil, medical director at the University of Sao Paulo

https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/z0U2kGdpGJ

name: BBCWorld
text:
But six months on, despite all that has been discovered, Covid-19 continues to spread around the globe

Read more about what has been discovered so far, and what still remains a mystery:
https://t.co/bR56VyKW8o https://t.co/clzzgPPcer
